awd_titl_txt: The Effects of the U.S. Trade Engagements on the Demographic and Spatial Distribution of Employment and Earnings
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

This project will provide insight into the labor market implications of alternative trade policies by highlighting the roles of multiple trade engagement channels, worker mobility responses, and price adjustments.  In particular, this project will generate a more comprehensive account of the earnings and employment responses to recent changes in the international trade environment among worker and firm types defined by combinations of characteristics such as region, industry, worker prior earnings, firm size and average pay.  The project will also provide a set of novel stylized facts about employment composition and earnings distributions among firms featuring different types of trade engagement.

This project will assemble a database that links the near universe of U.S. matched employer-employee records featuring worker demographics and pay with both firm-level customs records on all firms' export and import behavior. The project will also develop a two-sided assignment model that accommodates a rich pattern of sorting of workers to firms and market clearing in many interrelated labor markets defined by a large set of imperfectly substitutable worker types.  This model will incorporate changes in the level and composition of labor demand among import competitors but also exporters, downstream firms able to buy cheaper inputs, multinationals able to reconfigure their supply chains, and employees from non-trading firms that are affected indirectly through overlapping labor markets.  Finally, using the estimated model, this project will produce simulations of counterfactual scenarios that isolate the equilibrium impact of  alternative trade policies on employment and the earnings distribution among many worker and firm types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project #1949577 generated three research papers that have all been submitted to publicly-available working paper series and to peer-reviewed journals.
Collectively, these papers demonstrate that multinational firms that operate many establishments and trade with foreign affiliates disproportionately shape the labor market incidence of shocks to the international trade environment and the allocation of workers to jobs, locations, and earnings categories.  All three papers exploit firm-level data on international goods trade and establishment locations merged with job-level records capturing worker pay and mobility. 
Our first paper, ``Exploring the Hiring, Pay, and Trading Patterns of U.S. Firms: The Dominance of Multinationals Engaged in Related-Party Trade", examines how firms' engagement with trade predicts their pay distributions and hiring tendencies.  
We find that multinationals that export and import with their foreign affiliates 1) dominate trade volumes; 2) account for verydisproportionate shares of national employment and payroll; 3) employ greater shares of high-paid workers; 4) disproportionately poach other firms’ high-paid workers; and 5) offer their existing workers higher raises.

Our second paper, ``What Drives the Labor Market Incidence of Trade Shocks?: An Equilibrium Matching Analysis of China's WTO Accession'', builds on these descriptive findings by demonstrating how firms and particularly multinationals mediated the worker-level incidence of a large trade shock, China's 2001 WTO accession.  We estimate the impact of firm-level exposure to removed tariff risk on firm-level employment, and then use the estimated employment gains and losses as inputs to a model that simulates how worker-level earnings and unemployment would have evolved without the shock.
Our firm-level regressions show that:
1) Increased competition from Chinese products, both domestically and in export markets, led to substantial U.S. job destruction, particularly in manufacturing (633,000 jobs from 2002-2006).  However, increased access to cheaper Chinese goods also created an estimated 477,000 jobs in the wholesale/retail sectors, where many workers import, transport, and sell these products.
2) Because many large multinationals with primarily non-manufacturing employment also operate manufacturing establishments, around half of employment loss induced by domestic competition from Chinese products occurred at firms not categorized as manufacturing.  Some such firms also reallocated employment from manufacturing to non-manufacturing establishments.
3) Multinationals who import and export with related parties account for an estimated 77% of shock-induced employment losses and 62% of gains despite employing only 15.5% of U.S. workers.  Partly because such firms have high per-worker pay, the highest-paying (worker-weighted) quartile of firms suffered 50% of employment losses, while the lowest-paying quartile experienced net creation of 50,000 jobs.
Our simulations of worker-level incidence reveal that:
1) Workers at multinational manufacturing firms experienced the largest earnings and employment impacts (~$5,000 in lost 2002-2006 earnings) due to their firms' high exposure to increased import and export competition and greater ability to outsource workers' tasks.
2) Wholesale-retail job creation offset less of the worker-level earnings losses than the firm-level employment gains would suggest.  This is because a)  expanded import access generated disproportionately low-value, high-turnover jobs,  and b) gains per job created are smaller than losses per job destroyed, since destruction eliminates previously valuable firm-specific experience and forces costly job search, while creation requires search/recruiting/moving costs to reallocate workers.
3) Non-manufacturing workers bore 51% of earnings losses and 79% of increased full-year unemployment attributable to China's WTO entry between 2002 and 2006.  Initially high-paid and medium-paid manufacturing workers better succeeded in securing remaining manufacturing employment, and otherwise outcompeted low-paid workers for jobs in other sectors, leading those workers to search elsewhere, causing ripple effects throughout the labor market.
4) Consequently, despite greater employment losses at firms with mostly high-paid workers, shock-induced earnings losses and increases in full-year unemployment were larger for initially low-paid and unemployed workers who couldn't obtain or retain the jobs they otherwise would have.
5) Earnings losses were largest in the Midwest, but were less regionally concentrated than firm-level employment losses, despite substantial regional mobility frictions.
These results highlight how interconnected labor markets among different kinds of workers and firms spread relatively concentrated firm-level employment shocks to broad classes of workers across many industries.


Our third paper, ``Between-Establishment Mobility within Firms by U.S. Workers: Scope, Prevalence, and Effects on Worker Earnings'', measures how frequently U.S. workers switch establishments within their firms and assesses how greater access to switching opportunities affects workers' earnings trajectories.  We find that:
1) An estimated 1.4% of workers change establishments within their firms each year.
2) Within-firm establishment transitions account for 7.8% of job transitions, 18.2% of transitions originating at 5000+ employee firms, and 27% of between-state transitions, suggesting that large firms help facilitate regional labor reallocation.
3) Workers at the 90th vs. 10th percentile of earnings gains from more proximate access to within-firm job opportunities can expect 2% higher earnings over five years.  Such opportunities particularly drive earnings growth for otherwise stagnant mid-career workers.
Finally, the project funded two PhD students who took jobs that leverage their new modeling and statistical skills: economic consultant and analyst at a federal agency.
